factoid: Rostóv has been set down.
Rostóv died.
Someone told Antónov to help Rostóv up.
Someone told Antónov to sit down.
Someone told Antónov to spread out the cloak.
Rostóv was a cadet.
Rostóv supported his other hand with one hand.
Rostóv was pale.
Rostóv's jaw trembled.
Rostóv was shivering feverishly.
Rostóv was placed on the gun named Matvévna.
The gun Matvévna had had a dead officer removed from it.
The cloak spread under Rostóv was wet with blood.
The blood stained Rostóv's breeches.
The blood stained Rostóv's arm.
Túshin approached the gun on which Rostóv sat.
Túshin asked Rostóv if he was wounded.
Rostóv said he had a sprain.
Túshin asked what the blood on the gun carriage was.
The artilleryman answered that the officer had stained the gun.
The artilleryman wiped away the blood with his coat sleeve.
The artilleryman apologized for the state of his gun.
They used infantry to help get the guns up the rise.
They reached the village of Gruntersdorf.
They halted in Gruntersdorf.
The darkness had grown so intense that uniforms could not be distinguished ten paces away.
The firing had begun to subside.
Near by on the right, shouting and firing were heard again.
Flashes of shot gleamed in the darkness.
This was the last French attack.
Soldiers sheltered in the village houses met the attack.
The soldiers rushed out of the village again.
Túshin’s guns could not move.
The artillerymen, Túshin, and the cadet exchanged silent glances.
They awaited their fate.
The firing died down.
Soldiers talked eagerly.
Soldiers streamed out of a side street.
Someone asked Petróv if he was hurt.
Someone said they had given the enemy hot.
They said the enemy would not make another push.
Someone said they could not see a thing.
They said the enemy shot at their own fellows.
They said nothing could be seen.
They said it was pitch dark.
They asked if there was something to drink.
The French were repulsed for the last time.
Túshin’s guns moved forward repeatedly in complete darkness.
The guns were surrounded by humming infantry.
In darkness, a gloomy unseen river seemed to flow in one direction.
The river hummed with whispers, talk, hoofs, and wheels.
The groans and voices of the wounded were heard distinctly.
The groans were heard more distinctly than other sounds.
The gloom enveloping the army was filled with groans.
The groans seemed to melt into one with the darkness.
Someone rode past on a white horse with his suite.
The rider said something in passing.
Eager questions came from all sides.
The moving mass pressed closer together.
A report spread that they were ordered to halt.
Those in front had halted.
All remained where they were in the middle of the muddy road.
Fires were lit.
Talk became more audible.
Captain Túshin gave orders to his company.
Captain Túshin sent a soldier to find a dressing station or a doctor for the cadet.
Captain Túshin sat down by a bonfire.
Rostóv dragged himself to the fire.
Pain, cold, and damp caused feverish shivering that shook Rostóv's body.
Drowsiness dominated Rostóv.
Rostóv stayed awake due to excruciating pain in his arm.
He could not find a satisfactory position for his arm.
Rostóv kept closing his eyes.
Rostóv looked at the fire, which seemed dazzlingly red.
Rostóv looked at the feeble, round‑shouldered figure of Túshin.
Túshin was sitting cross‑legged like a Turk beside Rostóv.
Túshin’s eyes were large, kind, intelligent.
Túshin’s eyes were fixed with sympathy and commiseration on Rostóv.
Rostóv saw that Túshin wished to help him but could not.
Footsteps and talk of infantry were heard from all sides.
The infantry were walking, driving past, and settling down all around.
Voices, tramping feet, horses’ hooves moving in mud, and crackling of wood fires merged into one tremulous rumble.
The darkness was no longer a dark unseen river.
The darkness was a dark sea swelling and gradually subsiding after a storm.
Rostóv looked at and listened listlessly to what passed before and around him.
An infantryman came to the fire.
The infantryman squatted on his heels.
The infantryman held his hands to the blaze.
The infantryman turned away his face.
